entry.title: AngularJS plus MongoDB
entry.content:
Think outside the box.

We're past relational data. We live in the single page web app era with a preference for Node.js. MongoDB for things of great import, use the safe command:

collection.insert(doc2, {safe:true}, function(err, result) {});

Redis instances for all else, i.e., session storage.

No matter what though it all flows back to HTML; even stylesheets cascade down to an element.

With that in mind, let's explore whether AngularJS can help us craft real-time data binding with the type of model changes that push up without a page refresh from the user.

JavaScript is powerful enough to create real-time DOM updates on changes in our data model. But the language is often unruly.

AngularJS offers a unique solution that may simplify things. Compare to Backbone. In Backbone, data changes (and their corresponding events fired up from the data-model) bubble to the view. So we like to start by declaring a model. Then extend it to watch for changes on the model via getters and setters.

In completely different fashion, dependency injection in AngularJS allows us to declaratively describe how our application is wired. The approach in Angular is such that any JavaScript object can be a model.

Sounds good, right? Now let's see if we can wire some AngularJS CRUD to MongoDB... Check back soon for the snippet on how to do that, I'm working it out right now and I'll update this post soon with examples.
